bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Sylvia Hall Thompson was born Sylvia Bernard in 1924 in San Antonio, Texas. As a young woman, she joined the Communist Party and helped launch the Civil Rights Congress in Texas. In 1947, she traveled to North Carolina where she spent more than a year organizing electrical workers to join the union. It was there that she met her first husband, Sam Hall, a district organizer for the Party. The young couple moved to Birmingham, Alabama where, as open communists, they endured constant surveillance, threats and break-ins.

After Hall’s death, Sylvia moved to New York City where she went to work for the state Party office and met her second husband, Robert G. Thompson in late 1957. Bob Thompson had been a battalion commander with the Lincoln Brigade in Spain, and went on to receive one of the highest medals for valor – the Distinguished Service Cross – for his heroic actions in the Pacific Theater in World War II.

When he died in 1965, Sylvia sought and received permission from the Army to have his ashes interred in Arlington National Cemetery. However, when publicity about Bob’s previous imprisonment as a Smith Act defendant surfaced, the Army reversed itself and denied the widow’s request. Sylvia contested the Army's decision and in 1968, a federal appeals court ordered the Army to inter Bob Thompson’s ashes.

In subsequent years, Sylvia became a mainstay in the New York office of the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, working with veterans and organizing the annual reunions. Thompson passed away in 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the papers of union organizer and Communist Party member Sylvia Hall Thompson. Thompson's papers primarily consists of Freedom of Information Act release files related to Federal Bureau of Investigation surveillance of Hall throughout the 1950s and 1960s. The collection also contains a small portion of related to Sylvia's husbands Samuel Hall and Robert Thompson. Materials related to Sylvia's first husband Samuel Hall are comprised of a marriage certificate, photographs, Sylvia Hall Thompson's reminisces of her husband, and clippings related to Hall's activism and his death in 1954. Material related to her second husband Robert Thompson include a marriage certificate, correspondence, photographs, and materials related to Sylvia's effort to have her husband buried in Arlington National Cemetery. The collection also contain several articles by Robert Thompson, which were published in Political Affairs and materials related to Sylvia Hall Thompson's involvement in with the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigades.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Sylvia Thompson bequeathed two boxes of her personal papers to Tamiment Library in 2013. The accession number associated with this gift is 2013.047.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: At the time of accessioning, materials were moved into archival housing, and a collection-level finding aid was created to describe these materials. No physical processing or arrangement was done at this time.
